So, Schiller was not only set-up but it appears he's the victim of "creative editing." And which of the mainstream corporate-owned media outlets will cover that part of the story? Further proof that we need to support our public airwaves!

Perhaps liberals are, in general, too principled to play this dirty. But why not play the game and pose as potential funders to some of the "top" conservatives? The country would LOVE to hear what Gingrich, Palin, Beck and Bachmann say when they think they're having a private conversation with a potential donor...

Dave Carr has written a very thoughtful article -- something all too rare in today's rush-to-judgment journalism.  I'm particularly impressed that he could do it even before the truth came out: now we know that, yet again, the Angry Young Man behind these video "outings" edited the piece to make it seem that his subjects said things that they did not in fact say.  This is the third time, to my knowledge, that he's done this: first, in his Acorn videos; then, in his Planned Parenthood videos, and now, to NPR.  At what point will journalists and bloggers realize that anything he produces is more likely to be a lie than not?

Is another good Christian conservative lying his way to Heaven? O'Keefe's "creative editing" is fair and balanced massive lying.

Anyone who really tunes into NPR, meaning local non-profit stations supported by the users, would not call them biased. Just read a transcript of any of the news reports to prove it to yourself. Thus the reason they are growing their audience. The reason the radical right does not like it is it is honest and fair. That is just too much for them, honest and factual that is. By the way NPR audience 27 million, FOX fake news around 2 million regulars all in the same choir.

By the way I have many Republican and even very conservative friends who tune all the time. It is just plain and simple really informative radio. Way beyond the news.

As for the now totally discredited O'Keefe report on Ron Schiller has been proved a big scam (third time for O'Keefe) we know where the dirt bags of journalism are, oh wait not journalism it is just plan lying via video and scaming people. I wonder who pays O'Keefe's cost? I hope he gets sued to kingdom come for libel.
The fact remains that the 5 minute news summary on NPR is better than anything you can get from 3 hours of TV news.

Holy Cow! Did Youkilis and Shpigal really have to put down Banuelos? Especially after Banuelos made Youkilis look like a fool at the plate tonight?

Okay, so he's probably not Hall-of-Fame bound. Most pitchers aren't. But What was Whitey Ford doing when he was 20? Or Koufax? If a player's ceiling is so hard to evaluate, why put him down? It just seems mean on behalf of Shpigel--and utterly classlass on behalf of Youkilis.
Time to update the "About the Bloggers" section. Tyler is no longer in his first year as the National reporter etc....

I don't get it. MLB has a unique relationship with the Japanese people, and NOW is the time to step up in this incredible time of crisis.

MLB should donate money, give links on their website to charities, and hold benefit games throughout Spring Training.

Sure, the Yanks, Red Sox, A's donated, but in an unorganized hodge-podge way. The only word from the inept Commisioner Bud Selig is "devastating". Japan is such a great friend to the American pastime, and once again, Selig is clueless.

Meanwhile, MLB donated $1million within 72 hours of the Haitian earthquake in January 2010. I just don't get it.

The bank employee's name is Brian Penny. He's identified himself in public, and what he has to say is different than the version relayed by an Anonymous participant on Monday. The e-mails released have to do with flood insurance tied to mortgages. They do not demonstrate that anyone was overcharged, although a mistake was made, corrected, then partially hidden. Mr. Penny's version of what happened is here:

http://foreclosureblues.wordpress.com...

I have banked with B of A since 1966 -- no problems. But all of a sudden a $25 fee appeared on my
monthly statement with no announcement and no indication of why. In a fury I asked the assistant
manager in my local bank about this new charge. When I told this to an official in another bank
I was told that the FDIC had raised the fees that banks across the country contribute to the
FDIC funds and simply passed on the federal fee to its customers....
How's that chutzpah! I protested vehemently to the young woman dealing with my ire, assured her
it was not her doing but demanded that the new fee be returned to me and that no more extra
charges would be made while I shifted my money to another bank.
Try this one -- it might work for you.

So, he is worried what effect a terrorist attack will have on an unwieldy derivatives market?? I think we already found what the problem is with the derivatives market: a bunch of sober math majors with no brains. God save us all!

"Domestically, the president offered a budget so tepid that it effectively ceded center stage. He called for a few cuts but asked people not to get carried away."

It's funny that Obama's cuts are called tepid while the Repub's are called daring when both would save the same amount, with the only difference being that Republican cuts would have a significantly larger negative impact on jobs.
It's almost as funny that Obama is being called tepid in his response to a non-existent problem (the idea that the US is going bankrupt) for not doing enough to exacerbate a real problem (the recession).
Of course, you're also saying that Obama was aggressive in his first term, even though there was not one issue raised by Obama that didn't come with concessions to Republicans before debate started and be further negated with additional "compromises" as the debate went on. The stimulus was miniscule compared to total spending and GDP and was almost half tax cuts, even though any economist could tell you that tax cuts are an inferior form of stimulus. Pretty much the entirety of the government's spending increases are due to increases in the number of people qualifying for aid, and the majority of the deficit increase is due to falling revenue. Health care reform didn't even come with a public option. The idea of Obama being aggressive is purely a Republican fabrication with no basis in fact.

The latest example of President Obama's abundance of caution was his tepid op-ed in an Arizona newspaper about guns. He kept his talking points strictly in line with the results of current polling, which show most Americans want background checks for new gun buyers. But he was mute on Rep. Carolyn McCarthy's proposed legislation to limit the size of ammunition clips. Of course, this was a far cry from his campaign promise to renew the ban on assault weapons. He gave up on that pledge within a few months of taking office, once the NRA lobby received his undivided attention.

If Obama had campaigned on a message of caution, we wouldn't be so disappointed with his increasingly flaccid performance. It seems he is simply biding his time until the 2012 elections. He seems to avoid taking a stand on any issue, at all costs.

When we learned that his Organizing for America wing of the DNC was getting involved in the Wisconsin union demonstrations against Governor Walker, I rejoiced. I thought he was finally standing for something. Then came the news that an angry White House had reined in OFA, and barred it from participating in the fight for collective bargaining. Once again, I despaired.

Some people have criticized me for criticizing Obama so much. They have accused me of siding with the Tea Partiers by refusing to give the president a pass on his slow and steady drift to the right. My answer is that Obama, despite calling his base sanctimonious purists and ideologues, also once said we should hold his feet to the fire when we disagree with him. So I am taking him at his word.

Maybe if more members of his own party would be a little less timid, he might change. But I doubt it. The idealism of his campaign and the near-reactionary conservatism of his presidency have served only to cancel each other out and to create a vacuum of epic proportions.

Obama is not qualified for his present position. He never really was qualified. It was all a Madison Avenue show. He isn't passive; he certainly isn't wise; I'm no longer sure that he is even particulary bright. What he is is elegant and eloquent. He looks good and reads well.

Urgent action does call, David. But, no leadership will be coming from the Obama White House. Look to the Senate for leaders. Look to the House for leaders. But don't waste your time waiting for leadership from the Obama White House

..."I have no confidence that I can predict what sort of person Obama will be as he runs for re-election in 2012."

Hmmmm...Don't you think our chameleon President will be who he needs to be in order to win in 2012? Many Obama supporters in 2008 believe that to be true. He campaigned as a card-carrying Progressive. After the election he moved to the Center, slightly left. Now, mired in Afghanistan and terrorized by the Right, he has decided that being Republican-lite fits his needs quite well.

If Wisconsin Democrats start "cleaning house," and it looks like there is a groundswell of support for more liberal ideas, I am sure Obama will agree. If thisroves true, he will return more to 2008 mode since that will look like a winner!

This is our problem--and not just with Obama. We have politicians running our country today who do not stand for anything--other than their own ambitions. And our 4th estate. Yikes! Except for the alternative press, they are bought off wussies. Yep, welcome to America, the Corporation--playing at your local White House, Congress and--let us not forget--Supreme Court.

Oh, President Obama has been "adjusting" all along. We have not seen Candidate Obama since November 4, 2008. The guy in the White House is Bush III. Today he was "winning the future" with a plea to Republicans to tweak Bush's "No Child Left" policy.

Friday he was backing enhanced prisoner abuse, supporting the gross mistreatment of accused WikiLeaker Bradley Manning. By Saturday Obama had arranged for the firing of P. J. Crowley, the State Department spokesman who had the courage to speak out against the abuse of Manning. (Crowley knows a little about prisoner abuse; his father was a POW.) Of course the treatment of Manning is completely consistent with Obama's other moves to incorporate or enhance the Bush terror suspect treatment. Last week Obama also reinstated Guantanamo military tribunals. I guess he sees this as a safe political bet since most Americans don't really care what happens to terror suspects. They would if by chance they became suspects themselves. But they can't imagine that.

Obama makes Bush look like a wimp when it comes to prosecuting whistleblowers -- men and women who reveal instances where the government is engaged in wrongdoing. The Obama DOJ has brought more whistleblower charges than any other administration's DOJ. Ever. So much for Obama's vow of "transparency." What? We get to see the White House visitor logs? Big whoop. In fact, many "White House" meetings with lobbyists have been moved off-campus to a building where the logs are not made public.

In 2004, Senator Obama said, "I think it's a scandal that this president [Bush] did not force a renewal of this assault weapons ban." So this Sunday, President Obama wrote an op-ed for the Tuscon, Arizona Daily Star in which he advocated for gun control. Well, okay, not exactly gun control. He said the states should do a better job utilizing & enforcing existing laws requiring background checks. Assault weapons ban? Not word one. The Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence has given President Obama a solid "F" -- a well-earned failing grade. But it must really please George Bush and the NRA.

State Senator Obama opposed the Iraq War. President Obama escalated the Afghanistan War, which, by the time he did so, was just as unjustified as the Iraq War. Our reason for invading Afghanistan was to (1) oust the Al Qaeda & (2) nab Osama Bin Laden. We've never done (2), but (1) was accomplished before the Afghanistan surge. And despite his rigging the election & stealing billions of U.S. tax dollars, Hamid Karzai is still our puppet of choice. He just doesn't appreciate us as much as he did when Dubya installed him.

The Affordable Care Act, the one that so riled the astroturfed tea party, is a copy of an old Republican plan.

Obama's campaign promise to walk with unions was a sham. While teachers in Wisconsin were picketing, Obama was in Miami touting the "reforms" of former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, an early and continuing advocate for crushing teacher's unions.

The banksters are back in business, making the big bucks, gouging customers and cheating people whose homes are underwater. We can thank President Obama, Treasury Secretary Geithner & Ben Bernanke (a Republican whom Obama renominated as Fed chair) for that. The much-touted Dodd-Frank financial "reform" bill is a sham. Meanwhile, President Obama is promising to "ease regulations." Isn't that how we got into all this financial trouble in the first place?

I could go on. But you get the picture. President Obama is not Bush Lite, as some liberals have charged. He is a robust Bush III, working hard to out-Bush the Bush family, father and sons.

The Constant Weader at www.RealityChex.com

Prudence can sometimes look like weakness. Obama said his cautious reactions to the Libyan revolution amounted to “tightening the noose” around Qaddafi. Yet there is no evidence that Qaddafi is feeling asphyxiated or even discomforted. As he slaughters his opposition, Western caution looks like fecklessness.

Now I’d say his worrying flaw is passivity. I have no confidence that I can predict what sort of person Obama will be as he runs for re-election in 2012.

Typical of Mr. Brooks who in 2009 called for the President to show fortitude and increase troop levels in Afghanistan and the adoption of nation building in Afghanistan.

The United States is not the only nations with an air force. In fact the members of the Arab League, who now totally oppose Qaddafi, have sufficient military airplanes to deal with Libya.

Time for readers of Mr. Brooks to remember his support of nation building in Afghanistan.

Curious what lessons from conservative, Republican, President Eisenhower Mr. Brooks chose to ignore;

1) Ike knew wars had to be paid for and went after the rich with a 91% marginal, tax rate. One of America's unwritten rules is that the poor fight our wars while the rich pay for them. Bush43 broke that rule and Obama44 has run roughshod over it.

2) Ike, a conservative Republican, knew that a strong Federal government investing in infrastructure was critical to America's growth, witness his multi-hundred-billion investment to create the U.S. intrastate highway system, the type of smart, central planning that helped create America's wealth. Today, neither the Tea Party nor Obama44 has enough faith in America to invest in our, own country.

3) Ike warned against big banks and the "military industrial complex". Obama worships at that shrine.

But Ike was on the right in the 50's, before America moved so far right, even Eisenhowever looks like a radical socialist.

Brooks sounds like the Bush Administration "Chicken Hawks" who are responsible for the Quagmire Wars and Occupations of Iraq and Afghanistan.

While wearing Tasseled Loafers, the Bush "Chicken Hawks" forced our brave Army Boot wearing young men to die for the Oil Corporations and for the Military Industrial Complex Corporate profits.

No, Mr. Brooks, the United States should not enter the Libyan conflict and it is wrong to try to goad Obama into calling for any invasion or no flight zones.

Mr. Obama is Dithering around because he is a weak and feckless leader. Obama is not a complicated person at all. He is a Dithering Politician with a finger in the air to check which way the political winds are blowing.

He is neither an Eisenhower nor a Kennedy. Obama is a weak version of James Earl "Jimmy" the Peanut Farmer Carter. Though he was callow, idealistic and naive, at least Carter managed to serve as a Submarine Commander. Obama commanded a desk in the Senate for two years as his "greatest" credential.

Sorry to tell you David but Barack Obama will take his place behind Jimmy Carter as the worst president in modern history and his name should not be uttered in the same sentence as Real Giants like Eisenhower and Reagan or even Kennedy.
